text:
(1) James Slip, West Side and North from #13 left, a point midway between South and Water Streets to New Chambers Street. The two story structures with wooden stairs are Numbers II and II2. The frame house shown at the corner of Water Street being #9 James Slip. In the background appears the triangular apex, caused by the convergence of James with Chambers Streets and which forms the head of the Slip.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection,

(2) James Slip looking Northwards across Water Street.

P.L. Sperr,

About 1915

October 8th, 1938.
title: Manhattan: James Slip - South Street

text:
(1) James Slip, West Side and North from #13 left, a point midway between South and Water Streets to New Chambers Street. The two story structures with wooden stairs are Numbers II and II2. October 8th, 1938.
title: Manhattan: James Slip - South Street

text:
187 to 176 South Street, north side, west from and including James Slip, to and including Roosevelt Street. The houses shown beyond Roosevelt Street, (and appear as if directly under the Brooklyn Bridge) are facing on Front Street, as South Street at this point, makes a sharp bend southward. Also shown (right foreground), are Nos. 19 to 11 1/2 James Slip, at, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of South Street. Note the James Slip Gospel Mission occupying the corner house (bearing Nos. 187 South Street and No. 19 James Slip), and the adjoining building.
June 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

The same, from (No. 186) a point slightly southward, and viewed in a more southerly direction. The 4-story house (extreme left) shown, is No. 133 Roosevelt Street, at the S.W. corner of Front Street. This area is known to be the center of the waste paper trade of New York.
September 7, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

A detail showing only Nos. 182-3-4-5 South Street; the two latter numbers being the 5-story structures on the right.
1923.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
(1)

James Slip (right), west side, north from and including South, to but not including Cherry Streets, after crossing Water Street, showing the James Slip Mission at the N.W. corner of South Street. Also shown are 187 to 185 South Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W.
corner of James Slip.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, at a later date, showing a limited view on James Slip
(Nos. 19 to 15) and an extended view on South Street.
January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: James Slip - South Street

title: Manhattan: James Slip - South Street

text:
South Street, at the N. W. corner of James Slip, showing a building occupied by the James Slip Gospel Mission. This is No. 187 South Street.

October 1927

George L. Balgue, photo
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
South Street, east from and including James Slip. Shown in the foreground is the Manhattan Bridge. April 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
South Street, east from and including James Slip. Shown in the foreground is the Manhattan Bridge. April 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
189-194 South Street, north side, (right), east from and including James Slip, to and including Oliver Street, showing the South Street pumping station of the Fire Department at the N.W. corner of Oliver Street. Also shown (left) are Nos. 20 to 10 James Slip, east side, north from South (right) to Water (left) Streets.
May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
(1)
South Street, north side, east from James Slip, to and including Catherine Street; as seen from the Brooklyn Bridge, and showing a general view northeast. Note Knickerbocker Village, just west of the Manhattan Bridge.
June 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at an earlier date.
June 5, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 1 and showing a further view eastward. Prominent building, west of the Manhattan Bridge is a plant of the New York American.
April 16, 1936.

P; L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST.

title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
South street (foreground, buildings there upon), north side, east from James Slip (left, not seen in Nos. 1 and 2) to Pike Slip (under the Manhattan Bridge). The prominent structure seen is the plant of the New York Journal and American news paper. To the north of same will rise a large slum clearance project structure known as Knickerbocker Village. This appears in No. 3 in an almost completed form and will shortly be ready for occupancy.

January 8, 1934.
Views 1 and 2
July 31, 1934.

P. L. Sperr,
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip
